raw_text:
'Golden economic period' to end
 
 Ten years of "golden" economic performance may come to an end in 2005 with growth slowing markedly, City consultancy Deloitte has warned.
 
 The UK economy could suffer a backlash from the slowdown in the housing market, triggering a fall in consumer spending and a rise in unemployment. Deloitte is forecasting economic growth of 2% this year, below Chancellor Gordon Brown's forecast of 3% to 3.5%. It also believes that interest rates will fall to 4% by the end of the year.
 
 In its quarterly economic review, Deloitte said the UK economy had enjoyed a "golden period" during the past decade with unemployment falling to a near 30 year low and inflation at its lowest since the 1960s.
 
 But it warned that this growth had been achieved at the expense of creating major "imbalances" in the economy. Deloitte's chief economic advisor Roger Bootle said: "The biggest hit of all is set to come from the housing market which has already embarked on a major slowdown. "Whereas the main driver of the economy in recent years has been robust household spending growth, this is likely to suffer as the housing market slowdown gathers pace."
 
 Economic growth is likely to be constrained during the next few years by increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes, Deloitte believes. Gordon Brown will need to raise about $10bn a year in order to sustain the public finances in the short term, the firm claims. This will result in a marked slowdown in growth in 2005 and 2006 compared to last year, when the economy expanded by 3.25%. However, Deloitte stressed that the slowdown was unlikely to have any major impact on retail prices while it expected the Bank of England to respond quickly to signs of the economy faltering. It expects a series of "aggressive" interest rate cuts over the next two years, with the cost of borrowing falling from its current 4.75% mark to 3.5% by the end of 2006. "Although 2005 may not be the year when things go completely wrong, it will probably mark the start of a more difficult period for the UK economy," Mr Bootle.
llama3.2:1b: The US-based Deloitte consultancy has warned that the current economic growth period is ending in 2005 with an expected slowdown. The slowdown will lead to a fall in consumer spending and rise in unemployment, prompting a recession. Deloitte forecasts economic growth of 2% this year, below previous projections, due to rising interest rates and increased pressure on household budgets.
llama3.2:3b: Deloitte forecasts UK economic growth of 2% in 2005, down from 3.25% last year, due to a slowdown in the housing market and rising taxes, potentially triggering consumer spending and unemployment falls.
gemma2:2b: The UK economy is expected to experience slower growth in 2005 as the housing market slows down and consumer spending decreases. Deloitte forecasts a 2% growth rate this year, below Chancellor Brown's prediction of 3%-3.5%.  Deloitte also expects interest rates to fall to 4% by year-end. The firm highlights that the "golden period" of past decade with low unemployment and inflation is coming to an end. Deloitte believes economic slowdown will be compounded by increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes. However, they expect price inflation to remain manageable and anticipate the Bank of England to cut interest rates aggressively in the near future.  Deloitte anticipates a more difficult period for the UK economy starting in 2005.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The text discusses several points about the UK economy's performance over the past decade and its potential growth slowdown in the coming years, with Deloitte consulting predicting economic growth could fall to 2% in 2005. It also mentions that the economic growth of the UK has been hampered by a housing market slowdown leading to a rise in unemployment and inflation. The text emphasizes the need for the government to raise $10 billion annually to sustain public finances, while highlighting potential risks such as increased taxes and rising interest rates, which could slow down economic growth.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Deloitte predicts a slowdown in the UK economy starting in 2005 due to falling housing market growth and unemployment rising. Economic forecasts show annual GDP growth of 2%, lower than Chancellor Gordon Brown's 3%-3.5% forecast, with interest rates expected to fall to 4%. The firm warns that this could trigger a "backlash" on consumer spending and lead to increased unemployment. Economic concerns include growing household budgets and rising taxes, which will impact public finances significantly in the short term.
qwen2.5:3b: 'Golden' UK economic period may end in 2005 with growth slowing significantly due to a housing market slowdown. Deloitte forecasts 2% growth this year, compared to Chancellor Brown's expected 3-3.5%. The decade-long 'golden' era featured low unemployment and inflation, but at the cost of major imbalances. Deloitte warns that economic growth will be constrained by rising taxes and household budget pressures, with a potential slowdown in 2005 and 2006. The consultancy expects aggressive interest rate cuts to 3.5% by end-2006. Despite this, the economy is unlikely to experience major price increases in the short term.
opencoder:1.5b:
The Golden Economic Period concludes in 2005 with slower growth markedly. The City consultancy Deloitte has warned about a slowdown in the housing market that triggersConsumer spending and employment loss. It predicts economic growth is projected to be between 2% and 3.5%, and interest rates have fallen to 4%. In its quarterly review, Deloitte highlighted that the economy had seen a "golden period" during recent decades with unemployment falling near a low and inflation at its lowest since the 1960s.

However, the growth was achieved at the expense of major "imbalances," which Deloitte's chief economic advisor, Roger Bootle, said. Bootle stressed that the biggest impact of this slowdown is coming from the housing market slowing down. Despite growing robustly in the past decade, it faces a slower pace now due to increased pressure on household spending and rising taxes.

The growth is likely constrained during the next few years by increasing pressures on household budgets and increased government tax rates. Gordon Brown will need to raise about $10bn per year to sustain public finances without major disruptions. He predicts that this would result in a marked slowdown in growth since 2005, compared to last year's expansion of approximately 3.25%. However, Deloitte stressed that the slowdown was unlikely to have any major impact on current retail prices while it expected the Bank of England to respond swiftly.

The series of "aggressive" interest rate cuts, forecasted by the firm, with the cost of borrowing falling from its original 4.75% mark to 3.5% by the end of 2006 will likely render the UK economy more challenging for growth in subsequent years.
smollm:1.7b:
The Golden Economic Period ended with a slowdown in economic growth and a rise in unemployment. The UK economy suffered from the slowdown in the housing market, which was one of the main drivers of economic growth during the past decade. Gordon Brown's forecast for 2005-2006 economic growth was lower than expected due to the slowdown in the housing market. Deloitte predicted that interest rates would fall by 4% by the end of 2006, which is a significant step towards stabilizing the economy. The UK economy suffered from the slowdown in the housing market and the rise in unemployment during this period.

The UK economy experienced a golden period during the past decade with low unemployment and high economic growth. However, this period was also marked by imbalances in the economy, which led to a slowdown in economic growth. The biggest hit of all came from the housing market, which suffered from a major slowdown. Gordon Brown's forecast for 2005-2006 economic growth was lower than expected due to the slowdown in the housing market. Deloitte predicted that interest rates would fall by 4% by the end of 2006, which is a significant step towards stabilizing the economy. The UK economy suffered from the slowdown in the housing market and the rise in unemployment during this period.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text about the golden economic period in the UK and how it might change by 2005. First, I'll read through the entire text carefully to understand the key points.

So, the article starts by warning that the "golden" economic performance could end in 2005 because growth would slow down. It mentions City consultancy Deloitte advising against this. Then it talks about the UK economy's reaction to a slowdown due to the housing market: consumer spending falling and unemployment increasing. They predict a 2% growth rate for this year, below the forecast of 3% by Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

Deloitte points out that they had a "golden period" in the past decade with low unemployment and low inflation, but it was due to significant economic imbalances created by the housing market slowdown. They also mention Roger Bootle saying the biggest hit is from the housing market already slowing down. On the flip side, household spending growth has been robust, likely to drop as the housing market slows.

The article then talks about future economic constraints. Increased household budget pressures and rising taxes could slow growth. They estimate a $10 billion increase in public finances per year for the short term, which would cause a slowdown from last year's 3.25% growth. However, they expect moderate inflation even if prices don't fall.

They also mention that financial regulations will likely cut borrowing costs by raising interest rates to around 4%, leading to more aggressive cuts over two years. They warn about the Bank of England needing to respond quickly, maybe with a 3.5% rate in 2006. The conclusion is that while growth might be slow in 2005 and 2006, it's likely a start of a tougher period.

Now, putting this together into a concise summary without explanations or formatting.
</think>

The UK economy is expected to face challenges after the "golden" economic performance from the past decade. Growth may slow due to increased household budget pressures and rising taxes, predicted by Deloitte, which aims for a 2% growth rate compared to last year's 3.25%. However, they expect moderate inflation and potential price increases despite slower growth. The economy is likely to experience stronger household spending growth earlier but slows as the housing market slows. Financial regulations may raise borrowing costs, forcing interest rates to fall, with aggressive cuts expected over two years. Despite these challenges, the UK may enter a more difficult period in 2005 and 2006.
tinyllama:1.1b: According to City consultancy Deloitte, the UK economy is expected to enter a "goleden economic period" in 2005, with unequal economic growth and a backsliding in consumer spending triggered by slowdowns in both housing and household budgets. The forecast for economic growth this year is below Chancellor Gordon Brown's forecast of 3% to 3.5%, but Deloitte believes that interest rates will fall to their lowest level since the 1960s, with a series of "aggressive" rate cuts expected over the next two years. The slowdown in consumer spendings and rising taxes are set to constrain economic growth for the next few years by increasing household budget pressures, resulting in a marked slowdown in growth in 2005 and 2006 compared to last year's expansion. However, Deloitte anticipates that interest rate cuts will help alleviate some of these financial pressures and support long-term economic recovery.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary: The UK's economic performance during the past decade has been remarkable, with growth averaging at around 3% annually. Deloitte forecasts economic growth of 2% this year, which it believes will be impacted by a slowdown in the housing market and rising taxes. This is expected to lead to a fall in consumer spending and an increase in unemployment, although Deloitte expects the Bank of England to act swiftly to respond to any signs of the economy faltering.
phi:2.7b: The text reports that Deloitte predicts that the ten-year "golden" economic performance in the UK could come to an end by 2005, with growth slowing down and unemployment rising as a result of the housing market slowdown. The firm expects the Chancellor's forecast of 3% to 3.5% economic growth to be lowered to 2%, with interest rates likely to fall to 4%. Deloitte warns that this growth has been achieved at the expense of creating imbalances in the economy, and that future growth will be constrained by increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes. The firm suggests that Gordon Brown will need to raise about $10bn a year to sustain the public finances in the short term, but expects the slowdown to not significantly affect retail prices and anticipates aggressive interest rate cuts from the Bank of England over the next two years, with borrowing costs falling from 4.75% to 3.5%.
orca-mini:3b: The Golden Economic Period is coming to an end with growth slowing markedly, according to Deloitte. The UK economy could face a backlash from the slowdown in the housing market, triggering a fall in consumer spending and a rise in unemployment. Deloitte forecasts economic growth of 2% this year, below Chancellor Gordon Brown's forecast of 3% to 3.5%. It also believes that interest rates will fall to 4% by the end of the year. However, the slowdown is unlikely to have any major impact on retail prices while the Bank of England is expected to respond quickly to signs of the economy faltering.
hermes3:3b: UK economic "golden period" ending 2005, growth slowing to 2% (less than forecast 3-3.5%), housing market slowdown may lead to fall in consumer spending & unemployment, interest rates falling to 4%.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Deloitte warns that the "golden economic period" may come to an end in 2005 due to a slowdown in the housing market, causing a decline in consumer spending and a rise in unemployment. The UK consultancy forecasts economic growth of 2% this year, below Chancellor Gordon Brown's forecast of 3%-3.5%. Interest rates are expected to fall to 4% by the end of the year. Deloitte attributes the slowdown to economic imbalances and emphasizes that the Bank of England will respond quickly to signs of faltering growth.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK’s decade-long period of strong economic growth may end in 2005, with a slowdown driven by a weakening housing market, reduced consumer spending, and rising unemployment, according to Deloitte. The consultancy forecasts 2% growth, below the government's 3-3.5% estimate, and expects interest rates to drop to 4% by year-end. Deloitte warns that past growth created economic imbalances, with household spending—previously a key driver—likely to decline. Increased financial pressures and rising taxes could further constrain growth in 2005 and 2006. However, Deloitte anticipates aggressive interest rate cuts, potentially lowering borrowing costs to 3.5% by late 2006. While the slowdown may not cause immediate economic turmoil, it signals a more challenging period ahead.
stablelm2:1.6b: The "golden economic period" in the UK is expected to come to an end due to growth slowing and a potential housing market backlash, causing a fall in consumer spending and a rise in unemployment. Deloitte forecasts 2% economic growth this year, below Chancellor Gordon Brown's forecast of 3-3.5%. Interest rates are predicted to fall to 4% by the end of the year. Major imbalances in the economy have been created during this "golden period," with household spending growth being hit by a housing market slowdown. Deloitte anticipates increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes, resulting in a marked slowdown in growth for the next few years compared to last year's expansion of 3%. The bank of England is expected to respond quickly to signs of economic faltering, implementing aggressive interest rate cuts over the next two years.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The UK's prolonged "golden" economic period, characterized by low unemployment and inflation since 2000, may end in 2005 due to slowing growth forecasted at 2% by Deloitte, compared to Chancellor Gordon Brown's projection of 3% to 3.5%. This downturn is expected to be primarily driven by the housing market's slowdown, leading to reduced consumer spending and potentially higher unemployment. Deloitte anticipates interest rates will drop to 4%, aiming to mitigate the economic impact. The firm warns of increased household budget pressures and necessitated tax hikes for Brown to maintain public finances. This could result in a significant slowdown from last year's 3.25% growth rate, with retail prices likely remaining stable. Deloitte predicts the Bank of England will implement aggressive interest rate cuts over the next two years, dropping the current 4.75% to around 3.5%. The firm suggests 2005 might mark the beginning of a challenging phase for the UK economy.
reference: "Whereas the main driver of the economy in recent years has been robust household spending growth, this is likely to suffer as the housing market slowdown gathers pace."This will result in a marked slowdown in growth in 2005 and 2006 compared to last year, when the economy expanded by 3.25%.Ten years of "golden" economic performance may come to an end in 2005 with growth slowing markedly, City consultancy Deloitte has warned.Deloitte is forecasting economic growth of 2% this year, below Chancellor Gordon Brown's forecast of 3% to 3.5%.In its quarterly economic review, Deloitte said the UK economy had enjoyed a "golden period" during the past decade with unemployment falling to a near 30 year low and inflation at its lowest since the 1960s.Economic growth is likely to be constrained during the next few years by increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes, Deloitte believes.
